title: What will be the gross proceeds for special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) IPO transactions in 2021?
possible_answers: More than $140 billion but less than $180 billion
correct_answer: More than $140 billion but less than $180 billion
preds: I only had about 3 weeks of "all in" on the $180 billion or more bucket. This was based on the GRAB spac that I thought would add $40bn to the pot. It didn't, so here we are. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1356326
It seems I massively misunderstood gross proceeds, and Grab will only bring 4.5 bn, not ~40 ish... this one is going to hurt...

Inline with what @pstance has said, I think what matters is when the original SPAC raised money and not when it lists.
The gross proceeds can only be either the amount raised by Altimeter Growth when it went public or the amount raised by the company it acquired which is $4.5bn.
I think the former interpretation makes more sense. I should have clarified this before jumping to conclusions!

After reading the post by @pstance, I'm second-guessing my previous assumptions, so I'm going back to the crowd's odds until I get a better grasp of the situation with Grab. I did some more research, and Grab said it has raised 4.5 billion in gross proceeds from this deal, so I am using that as my number for Grab's gross proceeds: https://www.zdnet.com/article/grab-poised-for-nasdaq-debut-after-delay-covid-hit-quarter/ I'll update my percentages once I know for sure how the Grab deal shakes out with regards to gross proceeds.

I think there is some confusion as to what gross proceeds mean. Gross proceeds on SPACs are generated when a SPAC goes public, not when a SPAC merges with a private company. Thus, Grab's merger with Altimeter Growth Corp. does not generate any gross proceeds. Those proceeds were had when Altimeter went public in December of 2020.
Updated in line with news provided by @Scappleby. GRAB is coming to the NASDAQ

With the grab spac vote set for Nov 30 it now comes down to if the vote goes through (which seems most likely) and, if it does, what the value is.  Since initial estimates were 40B, and the current spac total is $150B, it seems most likely that a positive vote means bin 4. I'm not clear on when that vote would be counted toward the SPACinsider total (if anyone can shed some light on that it would be really appreciated). Seems 2-1 odds aren't unreasonable again so I'll come up 5%

This has been a really interesting question.
After assigning close to zero probability for the last bin for most of last year, now being forced to consider the possibility of Grab SPAC going through. 
Kudos to @Scappleby for getting this right early on.

Nov 30 vote for Grab. I don't know if the deal would go through on that date, or if there are more hoops to jump through before year end.
https://seekingalpha.com/news/3773032-spac-altimeter-growth-jumps-after-sending-vote-date-for-grab-deal
passed 140 so chopping that tail (updating) and adding to 180+ given some chance of a surge before year-end with excitement around DWAC for example, but seems very likely we dont pass 180
There's a nonzero chance Grab's SPAC goes through at about $40bn. If that happens, we'd crack $180bn. Shoutout to @Scappleby for the tip.
Now past 140b, so it's down to the final 2 bins and we're in the 11th hour... will Grab come through?...
over 135 w/ 2 months to go, odds of 140 are effectively nil ... some small chance of a late-year pickup in activity but seems highly unlikely

Currently at $130.3758 billion with 86 days left in 2021. Short about $50 billion. Average deal size in 2021 is about $286 million, meaning we need $50 billion / $286 million number of deals (or another 174 deals). The average number of deals per day was 3 per day from Jan 1 to Apr 1. Since Apr 1, the average per day has been .84. Big drop off. 30 day moving avg has been steady since July 1, at a little less than 1 deal per day. Estimating with this avg through the rest of 2021 (86 days) would be about 83 deals. 83 deals times $286 million per deal equals $23.767 billion. This puts us at about $154 billion for 2021 in total. Unless the pace returns to pre-April 1 rate (3 per day), or the deal sizes increase significantly, we're out of time to hit $180 billion in 2021.
mark to market for passage of time

Been tracking the number a little, it was $116B at the end of Jul and $126.3B as of today - that's just over $10B contributed to the total over 8 weeks, as there's 14 weeks left to year end, I think we can expect to see this finish around $140B

Currently at 125.9B, this entire question is coming down to Grab and I'm getting nervous as it's getting late in the game. It's still expected to happen late this year and if that happens at expected value puts us within striking range of 180b.  Realistically, there will need to be one more larger SPAC to push it over as the small ones (~300m) are doing the heavy lifting and there probably aren't enough to make up the other 15b on their own. So if Grab doesn't happen I'm really going to get hammered on this question https://www.forbes.com/sites/zinnialee/2021/09/15/grab-slashes-full-year-forecast-over-covid-as-it-looks-to-close-spac-deal/?sh=2a8c89fa397c

https://newacademyoffinance.com/how-to-invest-in-spac-special-purpose-acquisition-companies/#:~:text=According%20to%20SPAC%20Insider%2C%202020%20is%20the%20year,2019%20and%20US%2410.8bn%20gross%20proceeds%20raised%20in%202018. https://www.investopedia.com/terms/s/spac.asp https://www.skadden.com/insights/publications/2021/01/2021-insights/corporate/the-year-of-the-spac https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevenbertoni/2021/04/12/hot-spac-market-could-freeze-after-potential-sec-rule-change/?sh=6b220aa444c0 "Although SPAC IPO activity continued to climb well past record highs, the number of IPOs during 2020 were nearly four times the 2019 total. The first quarter of 2021 alone eclipsed the previously record-setting 2020 totals. The market now has begun to see a bit of a cool down." https://www.cnbctv18.com/views/decoding-the-spac-opportunity-9876861.htm "Additionally, the SEC has increased its scrutiny on SPAC deals. Most recently, with the change in accounting treatment for SPAC warrants. However, the current slowdown is expected to be short-lived as these developments are ultimately beneficial for investors, giving them more resources to bolster their trust in the process.
Given the current market valuations, potential capital gains tax changes, and the involvement of more traditional financial sponsors and financial firms, it is reasonable to believe there will be plenty of high-quality, private equity-backed companies and corporate carve-outs to support SPAC momentum for the foreseeable future.
The authors Aviral Jain and Aayushi Gupta are Managing Director and Consultant, respectively, at Duff & Phelps.

Updating my prediction based on slowing SPAC IPO listings.  TL;DR: It looks like SPAC Insider counts Gross IPO Proceeds as those IPOs that have moved into the "search" phase. Since April 1, IPOs moving into the "search" phase have fallen off a cliff. There are 191 days left in 2021. If this trend continues (49 IPOs/83 days = about 1 IPO every 2 days), we can expect an additional 113 IPOs to be filed by Dec 31, 2021. The average IPO size so far this year has been $311.8 million. If the average size holds steady, then we can forecast an additional $35.233 billion in SPAC IPOs this year. Adding in the $107.818 billion we've already seen, perhaps the total will approach $143 billion.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The question is asking us to predict Gross Proceeds of SPAC IPOs... which I believe does not include everything after the SPAC files for the IPO (its de-spac and merger with an existing company, which they have 2 years to do). Predicting what will happen in 2021 to all of the existing SPAC IPOs would entail a look at 2019/2020 SPAC listings, but again I don't think that's what the question is asking. SPAC proceeds for 2020 were $83.361 billion on 248 IPOs (spacanalytics.com). Looking at the "SPAC Status by Year of IPO" table at https://spacinsider.com/stats/ allows us to see the breakdown. The totals for "Searching", "Announced", and "Completed" are 248 for 2020. Similarly, SPAC Analytics says SPAC IPOs for 2021 totals 347, which is the total for "Searching", "Announced", and "Completed" for 2021 listed by SPAC Insider. I see a trend. So as the SPAC IPO is listed, the SPAC searches for a company to take public, announces a deal, then completes the deal. But, we aren't concerned with what stage the SPAC is at. We are only predicting if they'll move into the "search" phase based on their 2021 IPO. I think the "SPAC IPO Pipeline" row at SPAC Analytics shows what we are looking for: the number of SPAC IPOs that are awaiting the next phase- "Searching for a deal." This indicates 288 IPOs totaling ~$70 billion are waiting. Hard to say when those will shake free. We are currently sitting at $107.818 billion on 347 SPAC IPOs (314 searching, 32 announced, 1 completed). Since we essentially only care about IPOs that move into the "Search" phase, how likely is that?  The first 89 days of 2021 featured 265 IPOs (Jan 1 - Mar 31).
The past 83 days have featured 49 IPOs (Apr 1 - Jun 23). IPOs moving into the "search" phase have fallen off a cliff. There are 191 days left in 2021. If this trend continues (49 IPOs/83 days = about 1 IPO every 2 days), we can expect an additional 113 IPOs to be filed by Dec 31, 2021. The average IPO size so far this year has been $311.8 million. If the average size holds steady, then we can forecast an additional $35.233 billion in SPAC IPOs this year. Adding in the $107.818 billion we've already seen, perhaps the total will approach $143 billion.

With the wind heavily out of the sails there has still been an additional 1B in activity over the last 2 weeks (just over 105b currently). With that in mind, and 29 weeks left in the year, and with a few potentially large SPAC's in the wings, it seems more than likely to cross the $140b mark but heavily dependent on outliers to cross 180b (ie. Robinhood).  It would realistically only take one or two of these to push past 180b and there is active work being done to work around the new rules (https://financialpost.com/pmn/business-pmn/wall-street-grapples-with-new-spac-equity-contracts-after-regulator-crackdown). The 85% drop in activity in April/May vs the first quarter is unlikely to last and probably more indicative of learning how to work with the new rules. I'm betting it will be a few more months before activity really picks up again but the incentives are huge so I believe its more a matter of when than if. I'll dial back 5% from 89% over 180b until there is more news, or a major transaction.
Halfway through the year, and depending on reporting trends, more than halfway to 180.

We're at 104B as of May 24, it seems some wind is out of the sails with Buffets comments and the SEC taking notice but there's still some pretty big deals expected as the year goes on. I'll dial it back a bit from the $180 but still think its heavy odds to go past
Updating with more confidence now that April is over. SEC stepping in seemed to put a quick chill on the market, good to see.

Gross proceeds of spacs already exceed $100B.  Fitting simple exponential curve to last 3 years of SPAC gross proceeds leaves us with a projection of just under $180B. Fitting a linear model to the same data predicts ~$108B.  SPAC's seem to be slowing down in the last 2-3 months, various market corrections (see: SPACdex vs S&P 500 https://spacinsider.com/stats/) and new regulatory pushback (see: https://www.wsj.com/articles/spac-hot-streak-put-on-ice-by-regulatory-warnings-11618565403).  Given these factors, I find it quite unlikely for SPAC's to exceed the exponential forecast of $178B in gross proceeds for 2021. Of course, trying to predict the market is always a challenge and perhaps other forces unknown to me will re-heat spac markets. $180B+: 10%  Given SPAC's have already generated 100B in gross proceed as of early May, 140-180 seems the most likely to me: 55%  If SPAC's continue to be put on hold due to regulations and market volatility through the end of the year, the $100B-140B does not seem unreasonable, this towards the lower half of the projections (linear model outcome): 35%  These figures will be updated as new information comes to light.  I originally intended to answer this question back in late March: the following are my notes from that time... not sure they are  all still relevant...  Drawback's:
1) Rising rates makes pre-revenue/growth  companies less attractive (cash flows don't come immediately and are being discounted at a higher rate). SPAC's often target these sorts of companies. We see the market's reaction to this phenomenon. SPAC's are down considerably from their February highs, wiping out nearly all their gains for the year (down 15%). https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/04/spacs-are-becoming-less-of-a-sure-thing-as-the-deals-get-stranger-shares-roll-over.html 2) continued viability of SPAC target acquisitions
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/04/spacs-are-becoming-less-of-a-sure-thing-as-the-deals-get-stranger-shares-roll-over.html 407 companies IPO'ed in 2020, 247 SPAC IPO's, and a handful of direct listings... rounding to 650 companies total started trading publicly in 2020 ( ~40% via SPAC).  I question how many companies may be ready to become public. Let's assume there's some growth (5%) in the number of companies that go public in 2021, so hypothetically 680 companies go public in 2021. There are currently 400 SPAC's that are searching for companies to merge with and 200 already have done so in 2021. Let's say, conservatively, 50% of the searching SPACs close a deal in 2021 (200 IPO's). That would mean roughly 60% (400/680) of all companies that go public in 2021 choose the SPAC route. That's a 50% increase over the 2020 percentage, which many are calling the year of the SPAC.  Companies choose to IPO on their own terms, when they are ready. With SPAC's there is so much money floating around that SPAC sponsors may approach companies that are not ready to be publicly traded, but accept the deal anyways because the offer is attractive. These pre-mature companies may lose investors money, which will in turn make SPAC's as a whole less popular.

Already over 100BB, but momentum has slowed - issuance complexity, the diminished pool of likely or promising acquisition targets as  easy or good  targets have already rolled up, spotty track stock performance record of completed mergers, and investor fatigue in light of the prior  factors

Adjusting my estimate down from 100% "$180 billion or more" given the slowing SPAC listings. Per Bloomberg, SPACs are facing increased investor scrutiny and, more importantly, SEC regulatory hurdles (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-03-31/spac-listings-slow-to-a-crawl-with-bankers-buried-in-paperwork). From the article: "The SEC’s processing of SPAC documentation is taking longer than it previously did. In some cases, agency staff have warned lawyers that it may take a full 30 days to review paperwork and to expect an additional two weeks to hear back on changes or amendments." We're at $100 Bn now with 8 months to go, so I'm still confident the banks will find new ways to streamline SPAC paperwork. The increased oversight makes a lot of sense, but I'm surprised the SEC acted so swiftly.

Reposting link from @John-Baker (  https://spacinsider.com/stats/ ). SPAC IPOs fell of the cliff in April (~2.6B since April 6th based on @John-Baker data below ). It's unlikely they are going to resume much if at all. Most SPACs are trading below IPO prices and even the deal announcements do not bring much of a pop. There are 267 SPACs that applied for IPOs, but I doubt even half of them will IPO. This market is dead. It might not even get above 140B.

There is some feeling abroad in the land that new accounting rules and practices might put the brakes on this market pretty fast.  It may be useful to remember that "pretty fast" in the world of business regulation can mean anything from a couple of months to a couple of years, but I think I'll bump it down a little bit as a substitute for thinking too hard about it.

As of today, April 6, SpacInsider (https://spacinsider.com/stats/) reports 2021 SPAC dollars totaling $97.4 billion on 299 transactions. Thus, in only 3 full months, gross proceeds from SPAC IPO transactions are already more than half way to the $180 billion benchmark. A simple linear prediction would put the 2021 total closer to $360 billion. There are another 431 SPACs seeking acquisitions with proceeds totaling $139 billion (https://www.spacanalytics.com/). The average IPO size thus far in 2021 has been $325 million. If that average holds for the rest of the year, we would surpass the $180 billion mark with only 254 more SPAC IPOs, which is fewer than the number of SPAC IPOs that occurred in Q1 2021 alone. I'd wager we surpass the $180 billion mark June 8.

The crowd is super positive on this one while the deal pipeline does seem really strong 97bn worth deals done already. Only way that they easily cross that 180bn mark is if 2 things happen -  We see a strong bull market like what we have seen in the last year and crazy deals happen for longer. Remain doubtful there. Most of the SPACs have poor post merger returns

It seems unlikely this ticks under $180B over the next 9 months. 1. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/12/07/the-2021-outlook-for-the-booming-spac-market-and-traditional-ipos.html

Average SPAC size is now over $300M. As of Mar 26 there had been 296 SPAC's. There is a 4 fold increase in the number of potential spacs for the year already. Grab alone is estimated to be $40B. With an easier process and less restrictions it seems that shy of a disaster the total will blow past $180B
Mergers through blank-check companies are an increasingly growing share of the M&A market, with first-quarter volume already exceeding that seen in all of 2020.
Mergers through blank-check companies are an increasingly growing share of the M&A market, with first-quarter volume already exceeding that seen in all of 2020.

The first quarter is barely over, and the number of IPOs (275 "Searching"+ 1 "Announced" already exceeds 2020 total. There's a total of 219 IPOs (a leftover of 6 "Filed for IPO" of 2020 + 213 this year) IPOs already in the pipeline. More is likely to come, and even in times of rocky stock markets, the frenzy could continue due to a favorable structure (taxes? liquidity?). The structure likely also allows smaller and younger companies that are probably not mature enough for a conventional IPO to go public (ownership change) and/or stock owners to cash out, and even probably lowers the cost of going public relative to their market cap.
I consider at least 600 IPOs for the full year of 2021 to be perfectly possible. The average IPO size had its erstwhile peak in 2020, and shrank to 325mn on average so far in 2021, but as long as it exceeds 300mn in the end, gross proceeds will exceed 180mn USD.
